entry.et: Middle English, from Old English ceald, cald; akin to Old High German kalt cold, Latin gelu frost, gelare to freeze

def.dt: :having or being a temperature that is uncomfortably low for humans it is cold outside today a cold drafty attic
:having a relatively low temperature or one lower than normal or expected the bath water has gotten cold
:not heated: as
:served without heating especially after initial cooking or processing cold cereal cold roast beef
:served chilled or with ice a cold drink
:involving processing without the use of heat cold working of steel
:marked by a lack of the warmth of normal human emotion, friendliness, or compassion a cold stare got a cold reception
:not moved to enthusiasm the movie leaves me cold
:not colored or affected by personal feeling or bias :detached indifferent cold chronicles recorded by an outsider Andrew Sarris
:impersonal objective cold facts cold reality
:marked by sure familiarity :pat had her lines cold weeks before opening night
:conveying the impression of being cold: as
:depressing gloomy cold gray skies
:cool 6a
:marked by the loss of normal body heat cold hands
:dead
:giving the appearance of being dead :unconscious passed out cold
:having lost freshness or vividness :stale dogs trying to pick up a cold scent
:far off the mark :not close to finding or solving used especially in children's games
:marked by poor or unlucky performance the team's shooting turned cold in the second half
:not prepared or suitably warmed up
:with premeditation :deliberately was killed in cold blood
:bodily sensation produced by loss or lack of heat they died of the cold
:a condition of low temperature extremes of heat and cold
:cold weather
:a bodily disorder popularly associated with chilling
:common cold
:deprived of benefits given others the plan benefits management but leaves labor out in the cold
:with utter finality :absolutely completely turned down cold
:abruptly stopped them cold
:without introduction or advance notice walked in cold to apply for a job
:without preparation or warm-up was asked to perform the solo cold
:done or acting without consideration, compunction, or clemency cold–blooded murder
:matter-of-fact emotionless a cold–blooded assessment
:having cold blood
:having a body temperature not internally regulated but approximating that of the environment
:of mixed or inferior breeding
:noticeably sensitive to cold
:a telephone call soliciting business made directly to a potential customer without prior contact or without a lead
:money in hand
:a chisel made of tool steel of a strength, shape, and temper suitable for chipping or cutting cold metal
:quite limited sympathy, consolation, or encouragement
:a soothing and cleansing cosmetic
:sliced assorted cold cooked meats
